data.title: Convenient and clean
data.text: If you are looking just for a clean, quiet place to spend a night or two, this is a good value considering the location. It's a cute building in a nice neighborhood but could really use a couple of upgrades. Our bed was so creaky, it was still making noise after we got out of it! The wifi didn't work and the breakfast left something to be desired (if you are okay with cold cereal, pastry, and hard boiled eggs, this is for you). But nothing offensive, the staff was super-friendly, and we were able to park in the back - a plus.

data.title: Very clean and cute place but should improve breakfast, wifi etc
data.text:
Very clean, confortable beddings, very very close walking to the harvard square.
Some improvments have to be set : water heat is irregular during showering, breakfast is just almost none and no fresh items or almost none, bananas at most. Wifi broke down 2 days, they should reparait their system and also when a customer has several little complaints like these, the receptionist shouldn't dare talking abou half an hour delay at chek out..otherwise, kind people trying to help but too many small problems to solve. The place is secure and spotless though.

data.title: Great location and clean
data.text: The location is great with easy access to metro into downtown Boston. The rooms were clean and quiet. Breakfast was continental. The staff were nice and professional. It was a good deal considering the proximity to both Harvard and downtown Boston.

data.title: Good location, does the job
data.text: The location is its best value if you have Harvard business. The quaint room and bathroom were on the small side, but if you consider that this used to be a women's dorm ages ago, it makes sense. Everything was clean and made up daily. The service, hmm, depends on the person you get. The first desk clerk I met was very disoriented about our pre-arranged group lodging and payment issues. The clerk on check-out was super friendly.

data.title: Nice Stay
data.text: Great location, nice room. AC unit was a window unit, it was cool enough to open the windows.  Breakfast is limited.  The Inn was predominantly empty so we had no trouble with parking or sitting for breakfast.  The location is great.  Easy walk to Harvard and/or the Harvard station of the T.

data.title: Be cautious during Harvard events
data.text: We wanted a place to stay that allowed us to be car free, walking to the Harvard campus. This bed and breakfast is close. There are three floors with at least five guest rooms per floor. When we came for our first breakfast, we found three tiny tables, seating a total of eight people! We got our food, returned to the first floor and ate off our laps on a love seat. For almost three hundred dollars a night, this was not what we expected. Our room was very small, as was the tiny bathroom. Both were adequate, just cramped. There is an air conditioner in a window. The sliding panels that close the space between the air conditioner and the window frame just didn't work. There was a four to five inch wide gap on each side of the air conditioner. Parking is very limited, but not a problem because we walked or used public transportation. We reserved six months in advance and requested a ground floor room. We were initially assigned a second floor room, but given a tiny room on the ground floor.

data.title: Outrageous "Incidental" charges
data.text:
The review is based my one-night stay at A Friendly Inn on May. I was at Harvard for a conference. The stay was booked and paid directly by the university (about $250). 

The Inn is a lousy and depression place. Despite its prime location, some of minimal functions as an acceptable lodging are lacking. There does not seem to have an individual heating unit in the room. Even in May, the New England weather is so unpredictable. I woke up with freezing temperature at 4am. No mention how low quality of the bed, blanket, etc - far below Motel 6 standard.

The breakfast was a joke. There were plenty of pastries (like those cheapest ones one can get at Stop and Shop) which were not attractive to me at all. There were also some fruits and hard boiled eggs (cold served). The problem is that the food doesn't look fresh and seems to be there for many days already. 

Parking: this is the main complaint that I am writing the review. It may be very biased because of my personal poor experience. I checked out the hotel at 8am and went straight to the conference, while leaving my car at the Inn. I did ask if I can pick up the car later at 6pm after the conference. The person at the front desk was not sure about it, but didn't give me affirmative NO neither. When I picked up the car, I was charged $100 for parking, with the rate $30/hour. It is an outrageous rate.

Just for one night stay, my impression is that this Inn is not running a good business. Even during the busiest days around  the commencement, this Inn is still quite vacant (most of the people stayed there for the same conference). My feeling is that they are trying to make profit from any "incidental" charges. 

Compare A Friendly Inn with other lodging nearby. The Irvine house which is just next door, on the other hand, was very lively. My husband stayed there a few times, and was okay with it. We also stayed at The Charles Hotel a couple of times and loved it, but it is a more luxurious hotel (on the other hand, their valet parking is "only" $40/night).

data.title: Reasonably priced for it's location
data.text: This quaint B&B is within walking distance to Harvard campus and the T. Despite it's being located on a rather busy street the room was quiet and conducive to rest. Like a typical B&B the bathroom was small (but clean). I stayed in May on a warm day and could not find a way to adjust the temp in the room. My room was on the second floor and I carried my luggage up a flight of narrow stairs (no elevator). I agree with a previous review: all in all not the place to take your special someone for a treat, but if you're looking for a convenient place to stay near the university that won't completely break the bank, this is a good option.

data.title: Not great, not awful, reasonable "budget" option
data.text: For staying somewhere this close to Harvard, this place is a good deal because everything else around it is vastly over-priced. Friendly Inn is not always friendly - some of the staff are nice, while others were pretty rude (and I am not someone who is very demanding or difficult). The rooms are comfortable enough, but nothing special. It's a bit dated overall, but it is clean and quiet. So all in all not the place to take your special someone for a treat, but if you're looking for a convenient place to stay near the university that won't completely break the bank, this is a good option.

data.title: sticker shock
data.text: I'm told this is the best bargain near Harvard University. A Friendly Inn is a perfectly OK basic B&B hotel. But if this is the best you can get at the price near Harvard, my advice would be stay somewhere else and commute over to Harvard. My room was warm and clean (although I too noticed a long black hair on the bed!), the bathroom was well lit but tiny and misaligned, so that the mirror was not above the sink (much dripping on the floor while shaving) and the toilet could only be accessed at a strange angle, but it had what I needed. There were no tea/coffee facilities in the room and no room safe. The breakfast consisted of a lot of carbs and sugar plus hardboiled eggs -- not so great, but adequate. The coffee was like dishwater. In my case, the wifi worked fine. Overall, I would have said this was a good option, BUT... it cost over $200 a night! I wasn't paying, thank goodness, but I had sticker shock when I saw the price

data.title: Awesome location; poor temperature control in rooms and spotty wifi
data.text:
Location is ideal, walkable in 5 minutes to Harvard Yard, 10 to Harvard Square subway,buses etc. and also to excellent local restaurants (Dali, Bergamot). Within 100yards is a good cafe and convenience store.

Other good things: 
1) price is MUCH lower than any hotels
2) rooms have private baths, unlike some nearby alternatives
3) it's clean and seems well-maintained
3) there is on-site parking, 
4) free wifi
5) free breakfast (free) includes boiled eggs, pastries, fruit, coffee. 
6) Staff were friendly and helpful.

Not good things: 
1) there is no temperature control.  The rooms are heated by massive old radiators that raise the temperature to 80F in the room so we found it impossible to sleep
2) Opening the windows to reduce heat let in loud street noise. (Bring earplugs.) 
2) Wifi was very unreliable.  We lost it for 2 hours on 2 different nights, and when it was running it frequently dropped the connection. This made Skype and FaceTime impossible to use.
3) First room we had was very small (size of our spare bedroom at home) with OK storage and nice bathroom. Second room was larger with large bath but no dresser. 
4) Because there isn't enough parking for all the rooms (7 or 8 spots for 17 rooms) if you use your car you may not get a spot when you come back.  If you don't mind just parking it, it's OK. If you were planning on driving to suburbs like me, it's a problem.
5) Breakfast pastries were so stale we couldn't eat them.  Every morning we went to Darwin's or the convenience store to get food that was fresh. (The Inn could do this!)

Getting to our room involved two tall flights of narrow stairs.  Nice to have exercise but were glad we didn't have large cases. TV's were size of our laptop screens but we didn't need them because we brought out laptops :-)

Summary: The awesome location and "low" price ($200 once you add taxes) are enough to make this place a 3* even though we couldn't sleep. If they would fix the temperature so you could sleep and wifi so you could FaceTime/Skype it would be a 4* for people who want a clean, well-located room with private bath at a good price.

data.title: Convenient
data.text: Enjoyed our stay. Was close enough to Harvard and to subway to walk. Reasonable rate. Our room was on lowest floor and the stairs were steep and narrow so we had a hard time getting luggage up and down. Would definitely not recommend this particular room for elderly for that reason. Breakfast was exactly what we needed and served late enough that we didn't have to rush. Room was spotlessly clean-just kind of old fashioned.   Temperature was great.

data.title: Good location, clean, neat, and affordable
data.text: Great location, within walking distance of points of interest, and across the street from a library. Continental breakfast available. Good wi-fi. Very clean, well-organized. My room was small but well-lighted; my bed was not very comfortable but plenty of pillows are available. Staff helpful. Would stay there again

data.title: Good location
data.text:
As prices are very high at this location, this was a good price for the location. very close to Harvard with many stores, pharmacy and restaurants around. 
My room was ok size but bathroom very small and sink even smaller. Everything was clean. TV was more like a computer screen very small if you want to watch from the bed. I was afraid to turn on the AC as it was the old style not a split one. The lady said it was a quiet room. It was in a quiet corner but I could hear all the noises in the aisle and stairs.
Not a place I would come for a longer stay.

data.title: Pay for location?
data.text:
The accommodations here can best be described as “European”.  It is located two blocks from the north-east corner of Harvard Yard.

My wife and I stayed in Room 104 for six consecutive nights in early August.  Our room-rate was $187, but with the 14.5% tax rate added in, the total bill for six nights was $1284.  Our room with a queen bed measured 15 ft x 15 ft.  It had an adjoining private bathroom that measured a tiny 4 ft x 6 ft.  The bathroom contained a toilet, a tiny sink with a basin measuring 8 in x 12 in, and a stand-up shower with a triangular floor in which the long sides were 3 ft x 3 ft.  The furnishings were old-ish and a bit worn but were clean and fully functional.  The dresser drawers had an odd musty smell but looked clean.  Decorations were sparse; there’s none of the Victorian bric-a-brac that one can often find in more traditional bed-and breakfasts.

The free breakfast each morning was strictly continental, served in a common room in the basement.  It consisted of cereals, fresh fruit (bananas, apples and mandarin oranges), hard-boiled eggs and store-bought pastries.  Some of the pastries were above average; certainly better than the type found in a Hampton Inn.  Coffee, tea, milk and orange juice were provided.  The tea was bitter, but the orange juice was excellent.  It had the taste of not-from-concentrate from a carton.  Breakfast is served until 10:30 am.

There are six parking spaces provided in the paved back-yard of the inn, on a first-come, first-served basis for the 17 rooms that might be booked.  We were lucky enough to be able to park our car for five of our six nights.  On one night when the lot was full, we parked in a public garage a good half-mile away on the opposite side of Harvard Square at a cost of $28 for the night.  If you plan to just stay in the Cambridge/Boston area, you won’t need a car.

Unlike some of the tripadvisor reviews, we did not notice any noise from adjacent rooms and generally had a very quiet stay.  We ran our window AC unit at night on an automatic thermostat.  However on our first night, we were awakened at 1:30 am by a loud thump-thump-thump of water drops falling onto our outside AC unit from the AC of the room above us.  This continued all night and we got little sleep.  The next evening we taped a bit of cloth onto the top of our AC outside our window and had no further problems.

Our room and bathroom were kept very clean by the maids.  However on our first night in the room, upon pulling back the covers of the bed at 11 pm, we noticed a long black hair on the bottom sheet.  After fully pulling all the covers off, we found a total of nine hairs, both long and short, all over the bottom sheet.  The sheets otherwise looked very clean and the bed was tightly made.  I went to the front office to complain but it was closed due to the late hour.  But then after calling 0 on the nearby phone, a clerk immediately answered and came to the office within just a half-minute, and immediately gave me a fresh set of sheets to put on the bed.  Our room was otherwise well-kept during our stay and our one experience might have been anomalous to the standards of this establishment.

In summary, A Friendly Inn is nothing fancy but provides basic reasonable accommodations very close to Harvard.  I just can’t believe that they can get away with charging so much for such basic and small accommodations.  I suppose the price is for the location.  The competing inn next door has tripadvisor reviews that are equally disappointing and charge a higher price.  Hotel prices in the area are mind-boggling.  I think if I were to return, I might have to stay here again, but before I do, I would certainly spend more time checking out the offerings on airbnb.

data.title: Disappointed Big Time
data.text: Stayed here a couple of years ago and parking was no problem.  Made this recent reservation based on that and the third party website I used for the reservation, which said, " Free Public parking is available on site (reservation is not needed)."  Only partially true-yes parking is free but it is VERY LIMITED and if you missed one of the few spots available, you're stuck parking on the street, which can be a MAJOR challenge in Cambridge.  Our room this visit was TINY- small as in European small - like no real space for normal suitcases.  The stairs are really steep and narrow, which makes schlepping suitcases a true challenge.  Breakfast was okay - served in a dungeon like room in the basement, with regular choices like cereals, pastries, toast (but no butter), coffee, etc. Hosts are pleasant and the location can't be beat - 15 minute walk to Harvard Square and the Red Line!!  Beautiful residential neighborhood.  Because of the parking hassles and the size of the rooms, we won't return.

data.title: Convenient location for for Harvard Square and the university
data.text:
A Friendly Inn at Harvard Square is very close to Harvard Square and the university. The room, bath room and bed linen were all clean. Breakfast is included and consists of cerials, fruit, toast, hard-boilded eggs, 'sweet bread', milk, juice, coffee and tea.

We had a room on the ground level, facing towards the side-road, and we didn't have any noise in the room, as other reviewers have mentioned.

If you want a hotel with lots of facilities, and don't care so much about the cost, stay somewhere else. However if you want a place close to the university, and don't want to pay a fortune, stay here.

data.title: Not a great stay at this Inn ..............
data.text: The location of this Inn is ideal for accessing Harvard, but the facilities are inadequate - small room and bathroom, unfriendly and unhelpful staff, lack of heating. No kettle or tea facilities provided in the room. Expensive room rate for what is offered. Television signal disrupted when fridge opened. Would not recommend to other travellers ..............

data.title: close to everything
data.text: we had a small room facing the street. though the bathroom was tiny, the bed was comfortable, we could park in the back and best of all could walk to everything near Harvard Square. Also the windows open, which was nice for fresh air since it was warm during the day. Breakfast was adequate, but nothing organic, however there are so many places to get food nearby, both take-out and eat-in. It was once a girl's dorm for Harvard and has not changed much since that time.

data.title: Convenient location
data.text: We stayed here for two nights while in town for a wedding. The location is great: close to Harvard Square and the T station.  The inn itself was fine, nothing to write home about. It's an older building but in fine condition. The walls are thin so bring earplugs if you are sensitive. The bathroom was a little small, but adequate. I'm not sure if I would call the staff friendly but they weren't rude. I probably wouldn't stay here again unless the rate was considerably cheaper. We went on a weekend in late September, so I think our rate was at the upper end of the scale.
